Having trouble falling asleep even when you try to improve your sleep hygiene can be frustrating and anxiety-provoking. If you're struggling to fall asleep, here are a few additional techniques that may help:

1. Mindfulness meditation: Mindfulness meditation involves focusing your attention on the present moment, without judgment. This technique can be particularly helpful if racing thoughts or anxiety are keeping you awake at night.

2. Progressive muscle relaxation: This technique involves tensing and relaxing different muscle groups in your body, starting with your toes and working your way up. This can help relieve muscle tension and promote relaxation.

3. Imagery training: Imagery training involves imagining a peaceful and relaxing scene, such as a beach or a mountain lake. This can help calm your mind and reduce stress.

4. Guided imagery: Guided imagery involves listening to an audio recording that leads you through relaxing scenes or instructions for relaxation techniques. This can be a helpful tool for those who have trouble relaxing on their own.

5. CBT therapy: CBT therapy can be helpful for those who have trouble falling asleep due to negative thoughts or anxiety. A sleep therapist can teach you specific techniques to challenge negative thoughts that may be keeping you awake at night.

Remember, improving your sleep hygiene is a process, and it may take time and experimentation to find what works best for you. Be patient, persistent, and don't hesitate to seek professional help if you need it.
